 Emancipation

Why was Sam acting so stupidly in Emancipation? She's a prisoner of a man who has absolute power over her and she keeps flapping her pie hole about her lack of 'domestic virtues'. Anyone with half a brain wouldn't try to antagonize a man who could have you killed.

Precisely, instead "Ms. Brilliant" flaps her yap about how much contempt she has for 'woman's work' to a guy who could kill her with impunity. Not exactly professional.

Also, she suddenly turns out to be an expert on Botany and is such a skilled warrior she can easily defeat a guy twice her size despite the fact that there is no substitute for muscle. Were they trying to make the character unbelievable?

now heres the kicker,
martial arts is all well and good, but in a real situation, unless you are VERY good, there is no substitute for a big muscly guy going beserk, sure you could hurt him, but in the end, the guy just needs to shrug off a couple of painfull kicks, and tear off said defendents head...or something just as violent. In the heat of the moment, kung fu aint gonna make much of a difference against overwhelming brute force..in most scenarios.

I remember that when the first few episodes aired Amanda Tapping complained that she was being portrayed in a bad way, like she was always trying to be one of the guys. This episode was an example of this. I don't think that the writers were wrong to make a few episodes that seemed to dwell on the fact that Sam was a lone woman. It meant they dealt with the issue early on and could get it over and done with.

JoJo
Sam/McKay Shipper

Registered: Oct 2001
Location: City by the Great Shellfish Bay
Posts: 394

It's not that I'm so much anti-Sam, it's just that with a little thought, the writers could have made the character so much more believable. As it is, she's too perfect. She can solve every problem, every guy she meets falls madly in love, she can pound the crap out of a guy twice her size with ease, and I don't think that a woman would be on a first contact team in the first place. That much perfection really started to bug me ever since I began writing fanfic and really analyzed the characters and situations. Apparently even AT feels the character is 'too perfect' (I forget which site I found that nugget of information on.) She'd be a lot more interesting if she made a mistake once in a while.

It would have been much more believable if TBTB had had her working out of the SGC base with occasional trips through the gate. She still could have had a major role, and been fairly plausible.

I haven't seen 48 hours yet, Showtime won't run the episodes until February(!!).

It would be good to see a less perfect Sam.

As for the shipper aspect, are we supposed to believe she and Jack would wait years for each other. They should put their lives on hold for possibly a decade? That doesn't seem emotionally healthy to me. It would be far healthier if they would either decide to get over their feelings for each other, or one should retire or transfer out. Either way resolve the situation.

Friggin' please...

This "muscle beats skill" mentality makes me think that those who say it haven't really studied a martial art at all. Next thing you'll tell me is that medieval knights never studied how to fight with a sword?they just stood face to face and whacked at each other's blades as hard as they could until the stonger man sliced his opponent's sword in half and cleaved open his armor...

You seem to be forgetting one very important aspect about the final fight?Sam had laid that guy out on the ground, but even then I'll admit that she would not have had the physical strength to actually hold him down. The trick is, the chieftan wasn't even going to attempt to struggle. Why? He had a friggin' knife against his throat!!!

It was a knife fight, you idiots?not a fist fight! What is muscle going to do against steel!?
